results.title: Preventative action
results.creator_credit: Tasmanian Film Corporation, Don Anderson and John Honey
results.brief_description: Australian marathon runner Robert de Castella talks of his preventative medicine approach to lifestyle. Expectations of cure are very high in society but generally the public doesn’t want to actively participate in prevention. Poses the question: “Who is responsible for providing preventative health care services?”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tasmanian Film Corporation, Don Anderson and John Honey

results.title: Pretty woman (Director's cut) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Touchstone Pictures, Silver Screen Partners IV, Arnon Milchan, Steven Reuther and Garry Marshall
results.brief_description: Directed by Garry Marshall “Pretty woman” was the film that helped make a star of American actress Julia Roberts. Originally conceived as a film with a much darker tone, “Pretty woman” is a fairly light-hearted comedy. Edward Lewis, (Richard Gere) a businessman whose speciality is company takeovers, is on assignment in LA when he picks up a prostitute, Viv (Roberts), for the night. In the morning Lewis decides he likes what he sees and decides to hire Viv for a week’s round of polo parties and sex. Despite being somewhat gauche in her dress and manner, Viv is groomed for the part of the society lady, in a Pygmalion like transformation. Challenges ensue for the couple as they take a liking to one another beyond the bounds of their business arrangement. Each is drawn to the possibility that at the week’s end their partnership may blossom into a relationship. Also stars Laura San Giacomo as Viv’s housemate (also a prostitute) and Jason Alexander who plays Lewis’ sleazy lawyer. This special edition version of “Pretty woman” is the director’s cut.

results.title: Pretty village pretty flame = Lepa sela lepo gore
results.creator_credit: Cobra Film Development, Goran Bjelogrlic and Srdjan Dragojevic
results.brief_description: Set in the early days of the Bosnian War, this film is based around the relationship of two young men who find themselves on opposing sides in the conflict. Holed up in a tunnel, the Serbian soldiers strive to maintain their bawdy sense of humour while under siege from Muslim soldiers who are torturing and killing those around them. The continuing problem of accountability is highlighted, as soldiers on each side deny responsibility for the atrocities which have affected the other. Meanwhile, their country is torn apart. A powerful anti-war film that conveys the futility of war through the often ironic use of popular music, including a rendition of John Lennon’s “Give peace a chance”. In Serbian with English subtitles.
